div1.head: Report: Clinical Blood Findings in Yellow Fever, by J. Birney Guthrie, M.D. and R.T. Perkins, M.D., [1921?]
div1.opener:
CLINICAL BLOOD FINDINGS IN YELLOW FEVER
Miss
Y. F
Y.
J. Birney Guthrie M. D. and R. T. Perkins, M. D.
Tulane University, New Orleans, La.
div1.p:
The object of this work was to determine, if possible, whether any
characteristic picture existed which would furnish aid in the diagnosis of
this disease. To this end, we made a determination of haemoglobin, a count
of the red blood corpuscles, a calculation of the color-index, an actual husvey to count an examina-
tion of stained smears, and a differential leucocyte countbased on at
least 400 counted cells. This entire examination was made usually on the
first day of admission. In five selected cases which clinically were typ-
ical, a daily count was made until death or convalescence occurred, on or-
der to note the changes in the course of the disease, from day to day.
These serial counts are embodied in the paper.

The Thoma-Zeiss counter was used for the count of red and white cor-
puscles. The haemoglobin was determined with the instruments of Dare, Gow-
er, and occasionally with the Talquist Scale. We found that the Gower in-
strument was most useful owing to convenience, and comparison with the
Dare instrument showed uniform results. The Talquist Scale was unsuitable
fort the very high haemoglobin findings which we encountered. The von Flei-
schl instrument was used only in a few cases, because it was obtained only
near the end of the epidemic. The smears were stained with Wright's modi-
fication of the Romanowsky stain, or with the original Giemsamixturemixture,
after fixation in Merch's methyl alcohol. Sahli's polychrome methylene blue
and also haematoxylon, counterstained with 1-1000 aqueous water-soluble
cosin were also employed from time to time. These last two were used as
a comtrol and had no special value.

The stainssmears stained by the Wright method were most easily prepared,
and formed the basis for practically all of this clinical work. The Giem-
sa stain was the cleanest of all and this factor made it especially de-
sirable in the fascinating search for the parasite of the disease, which
at that time had not been found.

The cells which in our tables are classed as large and small mono-
nuclears, we counted and recorded as large and small lymphocytes- a class-
ification which was usual at that time(1905).

Table 1 was was tabulated from the results of the clinical blood
findings in forty-one cases of undisputed yellow fever. All doubtful cases
were excluded and all cases in which plasmodia malariae were found, even
though we agreed in several of these, that there was a double infection of
yellow fever in a patient who at the same time was the host of malarial
parasites.

As nearly as possible the same technic of the count was adhered to
by each of us, and frequent checking showed that there was a uniformity of
results. Variations from the personal equation of the one counting were,
therefore, we believe, small. The 41 counts recorded in the Table 1 were
made from the 1st to the 8th day of the illness.

All of the clinical findings we had collected were grouped and
put together into Tables 2 and 3. In these tables the findings were put to-
gether, classified, according to the day of the disease, and the averages
on these days calculated. Co-ordinates were thereby obtained which repre-
sented the average picture presented by our available data in fatal and
non-fatal cases, and the observations were made to as late a period as
they remained in the hospital. After the 5th day in the in the fatal cases
and after the 9th day in the non-fatal cases, the number of observations
are regrettably few. The average duration of the case in these series of
fatal cases was 8 days.

Our conclusions, based on a study of the pictures thus obtained,
are the following:

Haemoglobin in uniformly increased, averaging 11 in our series of
41 fatal and non-fatal cases. The highest recorded reading was 138%, in
casde
case 87, a fatal case. The lowest was in two cases, both of which recov-
ered- 80%.

There is nothing in our records which shows any marked difference
in percent haemoglobin between the recovered and the fatal cases. Nothing
indicates a diminution of haemoglobin of any marked degree in convalescence
or ever below normal. However, there seems to be an approach to normal as
convalescence progresses. This one would expect to see. The count of ery-
throcytes varies also with the haemoglobin; but the increase in even more
pronounced. The color-index for the entire series is.909. The maximum red
blood count was 6,808,000; this was in case 82, a fatal case, which also
showed the largest percentage of haemoglobin. Thelowest erythrocyte
count was 4,152,000 inc case 152 which recovered. This case gave a haemo-
globin of 117% at this time. The average red blood count in the 41 cases
was 5,892,000.

The actual leucocyte count was usually low and distinctly lower
than normal. Our series averaged 5,002 although there stand out in the
columns two counts, one, case 162, fatal, of 15,175 and case 124 fatal of
11,300. In neither of these cases were we able to determine the cause of
the relatively high leucocyte count.

The lowest count was 2,175 occurring in case 157, which died. There
can be no doubt that yellow fever is characterized by a diminution in the
actual leucocyte count,occuring in both fatal and more favorable cases.
No data of prognostic importance is indicated bty the tables, except it
be a confirmation of an impression we receive after a summer's work that
a high leucocyte count occurring early was a grave indication. All uncom
plicated cases with a leucocyte count of over eight thousand died. The
differential count of leucocytes shows some diminution in the large mon
onuclears, a slight increase in polymorhonuclears and small mononuclears.
The eosinphiles are markedly diminished. This is noticable even where the
existing existence of intestinal parasites had been demonstrated.
Basophiles are almost lacking. A very frequently encountered cell
in examination of the smear were “Ghosts” of leucocytes. These showed
no exoplasm as a rule and consisted of the rements of a reticulated
nucleus usually of the transitional approaching the polymorhular
nuclar type. Scattered about this nucleus were the granules stained pu
purple (Wright-Romanoskwy) which lay around the nucleus in groups as
if a rupture of the cell had occurred. These degenerated form were not
the result of technic in making the smears, for the reaction to the
stain was distinctly different. This type of cell does not find a place
in the columns of, our tables; but perhaps should have been included. It
is much more frequently encountered than in normal blood.
